PAMI.coveragePatterns.basic package

Submodules

PAMI.coveragePatterns.basic.CMine module

class PAMI.coveragePatterns.basic.CMine.CMine(iFile, minRF, minCS, maxOR, sep='\t')[source]

Bases: _coveragePatterns

Description:

CMine algorithms aims to discover the coverage patterns in transactional databases.

Reference:

Bhargav Sripada, Polepalli Krishna Reddy, Rage Uday Kiran: Coverage patterns for efficient banner advertisement placement. WWW (Companion Volume) 2011: 131-132 https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/1963192.1963259

Parameters:

  • iFile – str : Name of the Input file to mine complete set of frequent patterns

  • oFile – str : Name of the output file to store complete set of frequent patterns

  • minRF – float: Controls the minimum number of transactions in which every item must appear in a database.

  • minCS – float: Controls the minimum number of transactions in which at least one time within a pattern must appear in a database.

  • maxOR – float: Controls the maximum number of transactions in which any two items within a pattern can reappear.

  • sep – str : This variable is used to distinguish items from one another in a transaction. The default seperator is tab space. However, the users can override their default separator.

Attributes:
startTimefloat

To record the start time of the mining process

endTimefloat

To record the completion time of the mining process

finalPatternsdict

Storing the complete set of patterns in a dictionary variable

memoryUSSfloat

To store the total amount of USS memory consumed by the program

memoryRSSfloat

To store the total amount of RSS memory consumed by the program

Databaselist

To store the transactions of a database in list

Format:
>>>  python3 CMine.py <inputFile> <outputFile> <minRF> <minCS> <maxOR> <' '>
Example:
>>>  python3 CMine.py sampleTDB.txt patterns.txt 0.4 0.7 0.5 ','

from PAMI.coveragePattern.basic import CMine as alg

obj = alg.CMine(iFile, minRF, minCS, maxOR, seperator)

obj.startMine()

coveragePatterns = obj.getPatterns()

print("Total number of coverage Patterns:", len(coveragePatterns))

obj.save(oFile)

Df = obj.getPatternsAsDataFrame()

memUSS = obj.getMemoryUSS()

print("Total Memory in USS:", memUSS)

memRSS = obj.getMemoryRSS()

print("Total Memory in RSS", memRSS)

run = obj.getRuntime()

print("Total ExecutionTime in seconds:", run)

The complete program was written by P.Likhitha under the supervision of Professor Rage Uday Kiran.

This function creates coverage items from _database. :return: coverageTidData that stores coverage items and their tid list.

Total amount of RSS memory consumed by the mining process will be retrieved from this function :return: returning RSS memory consumed by the mining process :rtype: float

Total amount of USS memory consumed by the mining process will be retrieved from this function :return: returning USS memory consumed by the mining process :rtype: float

Function to send the set of coverage patterns after completion of the mining process :return: returning coverage patterns :rtype: dict

Calculating the total amount of runtime taken by the mining process :return: returning total amount of runtime taken by the mining process :rtype: float

To print the results of the execution

PAMI.coveragePatterns.basic.CPPG module

class PAMI.coveragePatterns.basic.CPPG.CPPG(iFile, minRF, minCS, maxOR, sep='\t')[source]

Bases: _coveragePatterns

Description:

CPPG algorithm discovers coverage patterns in a transactional database.

Reference:

Gowtham Srinivas, P.; Krishna Reddy, P.; Trinath, A. V.; Bhargav, S.; Uday Kiran, R. (2015). Mining coverage patterns from transactional databases. Journal of Intelligent Information Systems, 45(3), 423–439. https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10844-014-0318-3

Parameters:

  • iFile – str : Name of the Input file to mine complete set of frequent patterns

  • oFile – str : Name of the output file to store complete set of frequent patterns

  • minRF – float: Controls the minimum number of transactions in which every item must appear in a database.

  • minCS – float: Controls the minimum number of transactions in which at least one time within a pattern must appear in a database.

  • maxOR – float: Controls the maximum number of transactions in which any two items within a pattern can reappear.

  • sep – str : This variable is used to distinguish items from one another in a transaction. The default seperator is tab space. However, the users can override their default separator.

Attributes:
startTimefloat

To record the start time of the mining process

endTimefloat

To record the completion time of the mining process

finalPatternsdict

Storing the complete set of patterns in a dictionary variable

memoryUSSfloat

To store the total amount of USS memory consumed by the program

memoryRSSfloat

To store the total amount of RSS memory consumed by the program

Databaselist

To store the transactions of a database in list

Format:
>>>  python3 CPPG.py <inputFile> <outputFile> <minRF> <minCS> <maxOR> <'  '>
Example:
>>>   python3 CPPG.py sampleTDB.txt patterns.txt 0.4 0.7 0.5 ','

from PAMI.coveragePattern.basic import CPPG as alg

obj = alg.CPPG(iFile, minRF, minCS, maxOR)

obj.startMine()

coveragePatterns = obj.getPatterns()

print("Total number of coverage Patterns:", len(coveragePatterns))

obj.save(oFile)

Df = obj.getPatternsAsDataFrame()

memUSS = obj.getMemoryUSS()

print("Total Memory in USS:", memUSS)

memRSS = obj.getMemoryRSS()

print("Total Memory in RSS", memRSS)

run = obj.getRuntime()

print("Total ExecutionTime in seconds:", run)

The complete program was written by P.Likhitha under the supervision of Professor Rage Uday Kiran.
